S.FORM: mo mai pitu ne mi’o uhne ’oyonatmopsʉ.
S.TRANSL: 我今天七點到學校。
I arrived at school at seven today.

S.FORM: ahoi tmopsʉ, yʉmeʉmʉ to ’oyomia tmopsʉ ’o lema’cohio, mainca ’o letaayaezoi, “yac’ʉ! m’ohkuyu!”
S.TRANSL: 上課了，老師走進教室，班長說:「起立!敬禮!」
It’s time for class , the teacher walked into the classroom, and the monitor said: “Stand up! Salute!”

S.FORM: mimza tmunoi ho mainca, “’aveoveoyʉ lema’cohio.”
S.TRANSL: 我們大聲的說:「老師好。」
We said loudly, “Hi, teacher.”

S.FORM: mo seolʉa no tmopsʉ, isi pa’cohivi to lema’cohi tala hia tmasvʉtʉ no buacou.
S.TRANSL: 上課的時候，老師教我們數字的族語。
In class, the teacher taught us the Cou language of numbers.

S.FORM: mimza tmu’ofehni to lema’cohio ho engha, mimza pasu tmasvʉtʉ.
S.TRANSL: 我們跟著老師唸，我們唱了數字歌。
We followed the teacher to read, we sang the number song.

S.FORM: mo man’i ’o os’o pelʉi ci h’oe’ea cou.
S.TRANSL: 我學會好多族語。
I have learned many Cou languages.

S.FORM: la’u huhucmasi uhne ’oyona tmopsʉ, la’u huhucmasi aʉsvʉtʉ buacou, te’ola esvʉtneni to ino’u.
S.TRANSL: 我天天上學，我天天學族語，我要講給媽媽聽。
I go to school every day, I learn the Cou language every day, and I want to tell my mother.

S.FORM: ’a mo’o ’o ongko’u.
S.TRANSL: 我的名字是mo’o。
My name is mo’o.

S.FORM: ’a pasuya ’o ongko to amo’u.
S.TRANSL: 我爸爸的名字是pasuya。
My dad’s name is pasuya.

S.FORM: ’a sayungu ’o ongko to ino’u.
S.TRANSL: 我媽媽的名字是sayungu。
My mother’s name is sayungu.

S.FORM: mi’ocu tomaska ta tonsoha maitan’e.
S.TRANSL: 我今年10歲。
I am 10 years old.

S.FORM: mo cihi ’o ohaeva’u atai ’o ongkosi, mitacu tomaska veaucni.
S.TRANSL: 我有一個哥哥，他叫atai，他今年11歲。
I have a brother, his name is atai, he is 11 years old.

S.FORM: mimza yontomo conci ’oyonatmopsʉ.
S.TRANSL: 我們在同一間學校讀書。
We study in the same school.

S.FORM: a’o ho ohaeva’u lamza na’no kaebʉ pasunaeno.
S.TRANSL: 我和哥哥都喜歡唱歌。
Both my brother and I like to sing.

S.FORM: la’u kaebʉ yuhnguzu, homo seolʉa tosvo, lamza nʉtʉ ’o mimza conoemoo ho yuhnguzu.
S.TRANSL: 我喜歡游泳，放假的時候，我們全家會一起去游泳。
I like swimming. During the holidays, our whole family go swimming together.

S.FORM: la’u kaebʉ ho mi’o ea faeva ci nanghia, temiala melʉ toehungu pasunaeno ho yuuhnguzu.
S.TRANSL: 我喜歡認識新朋友，我們可以一起唱歌和游泳。
I love meeting new people, we can sing and swim together.

S.FORM: ’a oko no cou ao’.
S.TRANSL: 我是鄒族的小孩。
I am an cou child.

S.FORM: mo yone saviki ’o emoomza.
S.TRANSL: 我們家住在saviki。
Our family lives in saviki.

S.FORM: mo eimo ’o mimza conoemoo.
S.TRANSL: 我們家共有五個人。
There are five people in our family.

S.FORM: mo tuyu ’o mimza nanat’ot’ohaesa.
S.TRANSL: 我們家有三個兄弟姊妹。
There are three brothers and sisters in our family.

S.FORM: a’o ho amo, ino, ohaeva no hahocngʉ ho ohaeva no mamespingi lamza noteuyunu.
S.TRANSL: 我跟爸爸、媽媽、哥哥和姊姊住在一起。
I live with my father, mother, brother and sister.

S.FORM: mo bankake ’o amo’u, zou lesmo’eisi ’o amo’u.
S.TRANSL: 我的爸爸很高，我的爸爸是警察。
My father is tall and he is a policeman.

S.FORM: mo kʉehoi ’o ino’u, zou leaotothomʉ ’o ino’u.
S.TRANSL: 我的媽媽很瘦，我的媽媽是醫生。
My mother is thin and my mom is a doctor.

S.FORM: ’o amo hola yontoemoo lasi uaneni buacou a’mi.
S.TRANSL: 爸爸在家會和我們說族語。
My father speaks the ethnic language with us at home.

S.FORM: ho lamza tosvo lamza acʉhʉ maine’e ne huehungu.
S.TRANSL: 我們暑假都會回部落。
We will all go back to the tribe during the summer vacation.

S.FORM: a’o ho ma’ahaeva lamza tʉtpʉtʉ to kio.
S.TRANSL: 我和兄姊會一起抓青蛙。
My brothers and sisters and I will catch frogs together.

S.FORM: la’u na’na ʉmnʉa ‘o cou to emoo’u.
S.TRANSL: 我很喜歡我們家的人。
I like our family very much.

S.FORM: mimza yuyuso ’e ino ho covnʉ maitan’e.
S.TRANSL: 今天我和媽媽出去玩。
I went out with my mother today.

S.FORM: na’no tatposa ’e pepe homo hie, o’amo soyʉmʉ o’amo mu’ei, na’no sohuyu ’e poepe.
S.TRANSL: 白天的天空很藍，天氣不冷也不熱，風很涼爽。
The sky is blue during the day, the weather is neither cold nor hot, and the wind is cool.

S.FORM: mimza yootamo yaakukuzo ci ceoaho yaa bobonʉ, sliʉa ta hia co feango, na’no noyano.
S.TRANSL: 我們在草地上吃著麵包，陽光灑在身上，非常溫暖。
We ate bread on the grass, the sun was shining on us, and it was very warm.

S.FORM: ataveisi no cohzona, smoefʉhngya ’epepe.
S.TRANSL: 下午，天空變紅了。
In the afternoon, the sky turned red.

S.FORM: os’o tuocosi ’e ino, mancis’a smoefʉhngoya ’epepe.
S.TRANSL: 我問媽媽，為甚麼天空是紅色的。
I asked my mother why the sky is red.

S.FORM: yainca ta ino, teasonʉ cmu’ho na cmoehu.
S.TRANSL: 媽媽說，可能是颱風要來了。
Mom said, maybe the typhoon is coming.

S.FORM: uk’a ci meipeipi ta engʉca homo yofna, micu yuyafo si congeoha.
S.TRANSL: 晚上天上沒有雲，星星出來了。
There were no clouds in the sky at night, and the stars came out.

S.FORM: tetocu maezocu maine’e.
S.TRANSL: 我們也要回家了。
We were going home too.

S.FORM: smaimio ta ceono maine’e, mi’o mi’unu to feohʉ m’ea tooyokeo.
S.TRANSL: 在回家的路上，我跟星星許願。
On the way home, I made a wish with the stars,

S.FORM: atva’esi ʉmnʉ ote esmi na cmoehu, mi’on’a mici mimiyo.
S.TRANSL: 希望颱風不要來，我還想再出去玩。
I hope the typhoon doesn't come, I still want to go out to play again.

S.FORM: ’o la’u yoni ci ’oyonatmopsʉ mo nocmu’u to emoo’mia, la’u huhucmasi coeconʉ ho uhto ’oyonatmopsʉ, maezo la’u coeconʉ ho main’e.
S.TRANSL: 我的學校在我們家旁邊，我天天走路去學校，也走路回家。
My school is next to our house, I walk to school every day, and I also walk home.

S.FORM: o’a mo meoisi ’o lamza yoni ci ’oyonatmopsʉ, o’amo botngonʉ ’o ’o’okono tmopsʉ, lamza acʉhʉ yupa bobohngʉ.
S.TRANSL: 我們學校不大，沒有很多學生，大家互相認識。
Our school is not big, there are not many students, everyone knows each other.

S.FORM: la acʉhʉ yu’eteyunu to ’oyonayoyaso ’o ’o’oko, toehungu peispak’i to ma’li, noteuyunu ho aumomotʉ’ʉ.
S.TRANSL: 所有小朋友會聚在操場，一起玩球、一起聊天。
All the children will gather in the playground, play ball and chat together.

S.FORM: la maezo tes’upu ’amia ’o lema’cohio ho peispak’i, zou cono emoo ’e ’oyonatmopsʉ.
S.TRANSL: 老師們也會和我們一起玩，學校是個大家庭。
The teachers also play with us, the school is one big family.

S.FORM: lamza huhucmasi ateoteop’ʉcʉ, la acʉha tusi’nga ho poa cofkoya ’ola ’oyonavenkio.
S.TRANSL: 我們每天都要打掃，大家要把教室打掃乾淨。
We have to clean every day, and everyone has to clean the classroom.

S.FORM: pantola mahisi to pethʉ’ta, pantola tusi’ngi to aukukuyungu.
S.TRANSL: 有些人去擦窗戶，有些人去掃地。
Some people clean the windows, some sweep the floor.

S.FORM: lamza na’a tusi’nga ’o maucuculili to ’oyonatmopsʉ, lamza aangaeza ’ote hioa, huhucmasi na’no cofkoya ’o ’oyonatmopsʉ.
S.TRANSL: 我們還會打掃學校的各個角落，大家分工合作，學校每天都很乾淨。
We will also clean every corner of the school. Everyone works together, and the school is very clean every day.

S.FORM: ne hucma, mi’o uhto huehungu ho aitia ’o ak’i.
S.TRANSL: 昨天，我去部落拜訪爺爺。
Yesterday, I went to visit my grandpa in the tribe.

S.FORM: micu noana’o ho o’ana mimza ahtu yupa bobaito, os’o na’na taecingia.
S.TRANSL: 我們很久沒有見面了，我很想念他。
We haven't seen each other for a long time and I miss him a lot.

S.FORM: aiti to ak’i a’o, osnia pa’ni to vahatʉ a’o, pema to ’ocea.
S.TRANSL: 爺爺一看到我，就請我吃西瓜，請我喝茶。
As soon as grandpa saw me, he invited me to eat watermelon and drink tea.

S.FORM: na’no cohʉmʉ ’o isi emʉ’a to ak’i ci vahatʉ, aʉmtʉ na’no mafe.
S.TRANSL: 爺爺種的西瓜很甜，真的很好吃。
The watermelon grown by grandpa is very sweet and really delicious.

S.FORM: os’o yaeza ʉmnʉa ’o ’ocea to ak’i, maezo mafe ho isi ima.
S.TRANSL: 我也喜歡爺爺的茶，也很好喝。
I also like grandpa's tea, it's tasted good too.

S.FORM: cu cohiona, mimza iepoepohʉ ’o ba’i ho apapeipei’i tote ana no cohzona.
S.TRANSL: 中午的時候，我和奶奶一起煮午餐。
At noon, I cooked lunch with my grandma.

S.FORM: na’no toemamave ’o bai homo apapeipei’i to ’oanʉ no cohiona, mo yaa yoskʉa, yaa teo’ua, yaa pusiahʉa, maezo yaa kokeut’ee.
S.TRANSL: 奶奶煮了很豐盛的午餐，有魚、有雞、有南瓜、還有蝸牛。
Grandma cooked a big lunch, including fish, chicken, pumpkin, and snails.

S.FORM: oepʉngʉ ocohioni, mimza uhto chachae ho toa chae
S.TRANSL: 吃完午餐後，我們去菜園摘菜。
After lunch, we went to the vegetable garden to pick vegetables.

S.FORM: man’i ’o isi yaa to ba’i ci f’ue, ucei ho t’ocnga faeni a’o, pahafneni a’o maine’e.
S.TRANSL: 奶奶拿了很多地瓜、芋頭和蕗蕎給我，要我帶回家。
Grandma brought me a lot of sweet potatoes, taro and buckwheat, and asked me to take them home.

S.FORM: mimza yupa tooyokeo, tamzala vohvaho no ta’esi ho aiti hin’i.
S.TRANSL: 我跟他們道別，說下次再去看他們。
I said goodbye to them and said I'd see them next time.

S.FORM: maitan’e hafa to lema’cohio amia ho uhto ’oyonayuansou, mimza bitoyange to phingi ho mhia ki’pu.
S.TRANSL: 今天老師帶我們去動物園，我們在門口排隊買票。
Today the teacher took us to the zoo, and we lined up at the gate to buy tickets.

S.FORM: oh’aemonʉ to ’oyonayuansou, yainca to lema ’cohio “e tu’cusi zou mazozomʉ, f’uhusi zou mafkofkoi, temu iachi bobaito.”
S.TRANSL: so you can visit them yourself.""
After entering the zoo, the teacher said, There are birds in the front and snakes in the back

S.FORM: la’u’so smoyo to fkoi, ko’ko o’a te’o baito to fkoi.
S.TRANSL: 我會怕蛇，所以我不看蛇類。
I'm afraid of snakes, so I don't look at snakes.

S.FORM: man’i ’o os’o aiti ci zomʉ, mo meiavovei to ma’e’evi ’o mazozomʉ, maezo baito to puku cimo yoto feongo to evi ho oengʉtʉ.
S.TRANSL: 我看到了很多鳥，他們在樹上飛來飛去，還有看到貓頭鷹在樹洞裡睡覺。
I saw a lot of birds flying around in the trees and saw owls sleeping in tree hollows.

S.FORM: ’o ’aemona to ’oyonayuansou mo ya ckiu, ’uma ho e’uho, o’amo’ucula ahtu baito tamo maica ci yuansou, kaebʉ ho mi’o bobaito maitan’e.
S.TRANSL: 動物園裡有大象、馬和老虎，我從前沒有看過這些動物，今天看到了真的很開心。
There are elephants, horses and tigers in the zoo. I have never seen these animals before. I was really happy to see them today.

S.FORM: man’i ’o os’o hu’ongki, ta’u poa aitneni to ino ho amo.
S.TRANSL: 我拍了很多照片，給爸爸媽媽看。
I took a lot of pictures and showed them to my parents.

S.FORM: tamzala nʉthʉ ’e ino ho amo ho i’vaho uhtan’e no ta’esi.
S.TRANSL: 下次要跟爸爸媽媽一起來。
Next time I will come with my parents.

S.FORM: h’otosvo maitan’e, momza yuyuso ’o ohaeva no’u mamespingi uhne maibayu ho aiti ‘o amoconi.
S.TRANSL: 這個假日，我和姊姊去嘉義拜訪叔叔。
This holiday, my sister and I went to Chiayi to visit my uncle.

S.FORM: mimza ’i’mi ne taipahu ho yonto kuyai no tacvoh’i ho uhne maibayu.
S.TRANSL: 我們從台北搭火車去嘉義。
We took the train from Taipei to Chiayi.

S.FORM: mimza cu sʉcʉhʉ ne maibayu, poʉtʉcʉ to kuyai ’o amoconi uhto ’letosvakuyai ho suputi amia.
S.TRANSL: 到了嘉義，叔叔開車來車站接我們。
When we arrived in Taitung, my uncle drove to the station to pick us up.

S.FORM: o’amo nomcovhi to ’oyona letosvakuyai ’o emoo to amoconi, homo poʉt’ʉcʉ to kuyai moc’o osni sʉcʉhʉ.
S.TRANSL: 車站離叔叔家沒有很遠，開車一下子就到了。
The station is not far from my uncle’s house, and it’s just a short drive away.

S.FORM: cum’u to emoo to amoconi pantomo meoino leaʉtʉcʉ moatʉ’nʉ, mimza smopayo to zitensa ho uhto leaʉtʉcʉ moatʉ’nʉ.
S.TRANSL: 叔叔家附近有個很大的牧場，我們一起騎腳踏車到牧場。
There is a big ranch near my uncle’s house, and we rode bicycles to the ranch together.

S.FORM: yonto meoino leaʉtʉcʉ moatʉ’nʉ, hafa to amoconi a’mia ho p’onʉ ’to moat’ʉnʉ ho smopayo to uma.
S.TRANSL: 在牧場，叔叔帶我們餵羊和騎馬。
In the ranch, my uncle took us to feed the sheep and ride horses.

S.FORM: micu yofna, mimza evasʉzʉ ho uhto ’iciva ho eabobonʉ.
S.TRANSL: 晚上，我們一起去市區吃飯。
In the evening, we went to the city to have dinner together.

S.FORM: mo man’i ’o kuyai to ’iciva, ko’ko mimzac’o yonto ’otovai ho uhto ic’o.
S.TRANSL: 市區車子很多，所以我們騎摩托車去那裡。
There are a lot of cars in the city, so we go there by motorcycle.

S.FORM: ne temzacu mongoi, ’iamaihe peo’eoza ’o otovai’, ko’ko mimzacuc’o yonto vasu ho mongoi.
S.TRANSL: 要離開的時候，發現摩托車被偷了，我們只好搭公車離開。
When we were about to leave, we found that the motorcycle had been stolen, so we had to leave by bus.

S.FORM: mimzacu yuovei ne taipahu, o’a imza cohivi ’o ’otovai to amoconi isicu nana ahta elʉa.
S.TRANSL: 現在我們回到台北了，不知道叔叔的摩托車找到了沒有。
Now that we are back in Taipei, I don’t know if my uncle’s motorcycle has been found.

S.FORM: ne mo’una’a oko mosola yone tfuya’o emoomia, mo’ucula tmopsʉ, cu noezuhu ne maibayu, momeacula nochʉmʉ ne’e.
S.TRANSL: 小時候我們家住在特富野，上學以後，就搬到了嘉義市，一直在都市裡生活。
When we were young, our family lived in tfuya’o. After I started school, we moved to Chiayi and have been living in the city ever since.

S.FORM: mo’ucula tmopsʉ to taingakoo, mi’o tmopsʉ ho aʉsvʉtʉ to ceoceona no h’oyunsova ta cou, peela cohivi mo a’ʉmtʉ mav’ov’o ’o h’oyunsova ta cou ta taivang.
S.TRANSL: 上了大學以後，我修了一堂關於原住民文化的課程，瞭解到臺灣原住民族有各式各樣豐富的文化。
After I went to college, I took a course on aboriginal culture and learned that the aboriginal people in Taiwan have various and rich cultures.

S.FORM: ko’koeno, ieni homo tosvo ta tonsoha maitan’e, mimza yuyuso ’o ohaevano’u ahocngʉ ho maine’e to huehungumia ho bobaito to mamameoi, ocia cohivi na ceoceona no h’oyunsova ta cou.
S.TRANSL: 因此，今年暑假時，我和哥哥回到部落訪問老人家，想要瞭解自己族群的文化。
So this summer, my brother and I went back to our tribe to visit the elderly, hoping to understand the culture of our own ethnic group.

S.FORM: micu’so tonvoevʉhʉ ’o mameoi, at’inghi mioc’on’aso mais’a haah’o ho isi aiti.
S.TRANSL: 老人家已經八十歲了，但是看起來還像中年人。
The old man is already eighty years old, but he still looks like a middle-aged man.

S.FORM: os’o tuocosi cuma na osko peela ci e’e, mita na’no empompohsu ho mita bua cou, mita maezo meelʉ bua maaya, bua puutu ho bua sbukunu.
S.TRANSL: 我問他會哪些語言，他的鄒語說得很流利，也會說日語、漢語和布農語。
I asked him which languages he knew, and he was fluent in cou, as well as Japanese, Chinese and Bunun.

S.FORM: i’mi ta hia’u tuucocosi ho cohivi, ’iama mita ahoi ho mohtan’ala oko ho aʉsvʉtʉ bua cou ho bua maaya zou sbukunu ’o vcongʉsi.
S.TRANSL: 我問他才知道，原來他小時候學鄒語和日本話，太太是布農人，而他工作上認識許多漢人，所以他會說這麼多語言。
I asked him to find out that he learned Japanese when he was a child, his wife is an Bunun, and he knows many Chinese at work, so he can speak so many languages.

S.FORM: ne miza maica yupepeahngʉyʉ, ’e mameoi mo eʉsvʉsvʉtʉ tomo man’i ci tela hia e’ohʉ ho ea fou ci a’a’ausna.
S.TRANSL: 我們訪談的時候，老人家談論了許多關於狩獵的傳統知識。
During our interview, the old man talked about a lot of traditional knowledge about hunting.

S.FORM: e’vono o’a imza peela a’sʉftona acʉha ta’hongi, at’inghi mimza boemi to souci ho loku’in, tenamiala ivaha ʉmnʉ ci ta’lʉi.
S.TRANSL: 雖然我們沒有辦法完全聽懂，但是我們有用手機錄影，可以再仔細聆聽。
Although we could’t fully understand it, we could record it on our cell phones and listen to it more.

S.FORM: ahoi ne mo’un’a oko ho o’a o’ula cohivi na iachi ceoceona no h’oyunsova ta cou, a’ʉmtʉs’a iachi pa’hikokoe’i.
S.TRANSL: 小時候我不瞭解自己族群的文化，對於自己是原住民有點不好意思。
When I was young, I didn’t understand the culture of my ethnic group, and I was a little embarrassed that I was an aborigine.

S.FORM: fihta hia ausuhcu man’i na isi cohivi, cohivi ho cou ’e iachi, mo na’no h’unasi ci cou a’ʉmta atva’esa itanveni ci a’a’ausna.
S.TRANSL: 瞭解愈多以後，愈覺得自己身為鄒族人，是很獨特的，也很值得驕傲。
The more I know, the more I feel that being a cou is unique and something to be proud of.

S.FORM: yofna maitn’e, tac’u maine’e ’o ohaesa.
S.TRANSL: 今天傍晚，弟弟就要回家了。
My younger brother is going home this evening.

S.FORM: mimza yuyuso ’o ba’i uhto ’iciva ho mihia teo’ua, akoeva no pei’i note mafe ci oyoefona ’o ohaesa.
S.TRANSL: 我和奶奶去市場買雞，準備煮好吃的晚餐給弟弟。
My grandma and I went to the market to buy chickens and prepared a delicious dinner for my younger brother.

S.FORM: mimza esmi ’lemhinochai, mo man’i ’omo ʉmnʉ ci chae.
S.TRANSL: 我們經過了菜攤，有好多新鮮的青菜。
We passed the vegetable stand, which had a lot of fresh green vegetables.

S.FORM: mimza mihia miciveongo, f’ueofou, ho teikon.
S.TRANSL: 我們買了空心菜、山藥和胡蘿蔔。
We bought water spinach, yams and carrots.

S.FORM: yainca to tauke tomo nocmu’u ci momhinonchae, “’e ’ungeai ho kemomo’u mo na’no cohʉmʉ ’o. ma akei mhino!”
S.TRANSL: 旁邊水果攤的老闆說:「我的鳳梨和桃子很甜。買一些吧!」
The owner of the nearby fruit stand said: “My pineapples and peaches are very sweet. Buy some!”

S.FORM: mimza mihino to ’ungeai ho kemomo.
S.TRANSL: 我們買了鳳梨和桃子。
We bought pineapples and peaches.

S.FORM: mimza esmi tola momhino fou, yainca to tauke, “teko mihino no cuma? mo meoisi ho simeo ’e teo’ua maitan’e, mo se’tueva ’emo coni.”
S.TRANSL: 我們經過了肉攤，老闆說:「你要買什麼?今天的雞又大又肥，一隻300元。」
We passed the meat stall, and the boss said, “What do you want to buy? Today’s chickens are big and fat, and one is 300 NTD.”

S.FORM: isi anga pepea to ba’i, tuocosi ’o tauke te ʉmnʉ oci ake’a poa cʉecʉa.
S.TRANSL: 奶奶覺得太貴了，問老闆可不可以便宜一點。
Grandma thought it was too expensive and asked the boss if it could be cheaper.

S.FORM: at’inghi isi yainca to tauke mic na’no cʉecʉ, ’anate peela ashca poa cʉecʉa.
S.TRANSL: 但老闆說已經很便宜，不能再減了。
But the boss said that it is already very cheap and cannot be reduced any further.

S.FORM: yainca tomo nochipi ci tauke, mihino ta yosku’u, mo meisi ho cʉecʉ ’e yosku’u.
S.TRANSL: 隔壁的老闆說，來買我的魚，我的魚又大又便宜。
The boss next door said, come and buy my fish, my fish is big and cheap.

S.FORM: mimza atavei mihino to teo’ua maezo mihino to yoskʉ, cono panka ’o imza pe’i ci chae ne mimza cu maine’e.
S.TRANSL: 最後我們買了雞也買了魚，回家煮了一桌子的菜。
In the end we bought chicken and fish, and went home to cook a table of food.

S.FORM: noana’o mooteo, cu petohʉyʉ ’eopsi.
S.TRANSL: 等了好久，天已經黑了。
After waiting for a long time, it was already dark.

S.FORM: psoemio to memeno ’o ohaesa yainca, akameosʉ o’ate azou tosva ’e heetai, ta’esi no nicio nate’o mee’lʉ maine’e.
S.TRANSL: 弟弟打電話回來說，軍隊突然不能放假了，要下一個禮拜日才回來。
The younger brother called back and said that the army suddenly couldn’t take a vacation and would not be back until the next Sunday.

S.FORM: yainca to ba’i micu toeman’i tate ana, cu acʉhʉ yabobonʉ!
S.TRANSL: 奶奶說已經煮了這麼多，叫大家一起來吃吧!
Grandma said that she has cooked so much, so let’s eat together!

S.FORM: mimza yoho’ʉ ’to ma’o’oahngʉ maanananghia, acʉhʉ tiou tomo ʉmnʉ ci hia yaabobonʉ oyoefonʉ.
S.TRANSL: 我們邀請了親朋好友，一起來享用豐盛的晚餐。
We invited friends and family to have a great dinner together.

S.FORM: mo cihi ’o mimza tmahmʉhmʉsku zou pasuya ’o ongkosi, la luema’payo’ʉ mahafa ’to macucumasi.
S.TRANSL: 我有一個同學叫pasuya，他常常忘記帶東西。
I have a classmate named pasuya, he often forgets to bring things.

S.FORM: ho la tmopsʉ, la mi’unu tomo tmahmʉhmʉskʉ ho yuevaho to lesmapayo’ʉ ho letposi.
S.TRANSL: 上課的時候，他跟同學借鉛筆、橡皮擦或是筆記本。
During class, he borrowed pencils, erasers or notebooks from his classmates.

S.FORM: y’ʉnʉskʉ, i’popsohʉ, i’toteuhu, lahen’a yuvahneni to nacucuma.
S.TRANSL: 一次、兩次、三次，大家會借東西給他。
Once, twice, three times, everyone would lend him something.

S.FORM: ati’nghi pantolata kuici hioa, lata asngʉcʉ yuvaho to macucumahe ho oh’te yooveineni.
S.TRANSL: 但是他有個壞習慣，經常借了東西卻不還。
But he has a bad habit of often borrowing things but not returning them.

S.FORM: ko’ko o’a na ohe’la ucia poa yuvahneni to macucumahe.
S.TRANSL: 最後大家都不想借他東西了。
In the end, no one wanted to borrow anything from him.

S.FORM: mosola conohiea, mozala nʉthʉhʉ mimiyo.
S.TRANSL: 有一天，我們大家一起去郊遊。
One day, we all went on an outing together.

S.FORM: momza seolʉano emo’usnumaica, akameosʉ na’no mici te’i ’o pasuya, at’enghi ’iamamita tapayo’ʉ mahafo tola titha mahisipcoo ci kami.
S.TRANSL: 路途中，pasuya想上廁所，但他忘記帶衛生紙。
On the way, pasuya wanted to go to the bathroom, but he forgot to bring toilet paper.

S.FORM: mita mi’usnu to mihini tmahmʉhmʉsku ’e pasuya ho yuvaho to letithamahisi teta akoyu no ohse’u, atng’ihi mo acʉhʉ mainca, maezo o’a mi’os’a mahafo.
S.TRANSL: 他跟同學借衛生紙，可是大家都回他說，我也沒有帶耶。
He borrowed toilet paper from his classmates, but everyone told him that I didn’t bring them either.

S.FORM: mitacu amio tmumongsi ’e pasuya. mita sʉ’no ho mainca, maincis’a o’te poa yuvahoa to letithamahisi.
S.TRANSL: pasuya急的哭了出來。他生氣的說，為什麼大家都不借我衛生紙!
pasuya burst into tears. He said angrily, why don’t everyone lend me toilet paper!

S.FORM: yainca to mihimn’i tmahmʉhmʉskʉ, ’a miko no’so ’ote iachi mahafo, a’vinano inante yuvahnenisu ci macucuma, ana tekos’a ahta yoveineni.
S.TRANSL: 同學告訴他，因為你都不自己帶，而且借給你的東西，你都不會還!
The classmate told him, because you didn’t bring it yourself, and you wouldn’t return the things lent to you!

S.FORM: micu hucma tec’u uhuto ’oyonatmopsʉ, mo sʉfeʉnʉ ’o pasuya uhto ’oyonatmpsʉ, ita acʉha yoveineni to mihimni tmahmʉhmʉskʉ ’o ohtala yuvaha ci macucuma.
S.TRANSL: 隔天上學，pasuya很早就到學校了，pasuya把跟同學借的東西都還給同學們。
The next day at school, pasuya arrived at school early and returned everything he had borrowed from his classmates.

S.FORM: mi’usnu to mihimn’i tmahmʉhmʉskʉ ho ’aveoveoyʉ ’e pasuya, mainca, ta’ucula iachi mahavo no macucuma, ’aveoveoneni to mimza tmahmʉhmʉskʉ ihingn’i yuvahneni to macucuma ne auyusi.
S.TRANSL: pasuya向同學們道歉，並說他以後一定會自己帶東西，也謝謝同學們之前願意借他東西。
pasuya apologized to the students and said that he would definitely bring his own things in the future, and thanked the classmates for their willingness to lend him things before.

S.FORM: leyafou to huehungu ’o amo’u.
S.TRANSL: 我的爸爸是部落的獵人。
My dad is a hunter of the tribe.

S.FORM: mo’un’ala oko, la e’ohʉ homo yofna ’o amo ho amoconi, la smu’iei ho teos’ofʉ.
S.TRANSL: 我小的時候，爸爸和叔叔會在晚上出門，帶著獵刀和獵槍。
When I was little, my dad and uncle would go out at night with hunting knives and guns.

S.FORM: tac’u tiskova, tahecu hafa maine’e ’o ihe poumia ci yuansou.
S.TRANSL: 天亮時，他們就會帶著獵到的獵物回來。
At daybreak, they returned with their prey.

S.FORM: la asvʉtʉ mayo to fuzu, aasvʉtʉc’o voyʉ, la aasvʉtʉ mayo to toevosʉ.
S.TRANSL: 有時候是山豬、有時候是飛鼠，偶爾也會有雉雞。
Sometimes it was a boar, sometimes a flying squirrel, and occasionally a pheasant.

S.FORM: lahe na’nosino aueva angaeza na’a, tahecu angaezneni to ma’o’oahngʉ.
S.TRANSL: 他們會在村口將獵物分好，分享給族人。
They would divide the prey at the entrance of the village and share it with the tribe.

S.FORM: la’u ’aoko m’ea viho to amo, mici fiho to amo ho e’ohʉ.
S.TRANSL: 我每次都會吵著爸爸，要跟著爸爸去打獵。
Every time I quarreled with my father, I wanted to go hunting with my father.

S.FORM: yainca to amo ieni ho ta’ucula saasmoyʉskʉ tasicula yuyusveni ho i’ohʉ.
S.TRANSL: 爸爸說等我長大了他再帶我一起去。
Dad said that he would take me with me when I grew up.

S.FORM: ’o hahocngʉ to huehungu la maezo melʉ titho to h’oepona ho boepono to yuansou, la meelʉ moyai to vomʉ no h’oepona ho tocʉvʉ.
S.TRANSL: 部落的男人也會用陷阱抓獵物，他們會製作套索陷阱和石壓式陷阱。
The men of the tribe also trap their prey, making lasso traps and rock traps.

S.FORM: ’o amo’u la saihu homo moyai h’oepona no evomʉ, yainca to amo, la titha boepono to toevosʉ eni, tetola yaeza yue’ia ’o lasi p’ecihi to yuansou, la sia to huyusi to yuansou ’o h’oepona.
S.TRANSL: 我的爸爸很會製作套索陷阱，爸爸說，這是用來捕抓雉雞的，我們要仔細觀察獵物的腳印，陷阱要放在獵物走的路上。

My dad is very good at making lasso traps. Dad said that this is used to catch pheasants. We have to carefully observe the footprints of the prey, and the traps should be placed on the path of the prey.

S.FORM: akoyu no aupcio mel’ʉ fiho to mamameoi ho e’ohʉ, la’u huhucmasi aʉsvʉtʉ boepono, c’o osni yaa mumza to h’oepona’u ci yuansou.
S.TRANSL: 為了可以趕快和大人一起去打獵，我每天練習製作陷阱，很快地我的陷阱就真的可以抓到獵物了。
In order to go hunting with adults as soon as possible, I practiced making traps every day, and soon my traps can really catch prey.

S.FORM: mi’uni to amo’u yainca takola ahtuo’te leyaafou ci cou.
S.TRANSL: 爸爸看到後對我說我以後一定會是很厲害的獵人。
Dad saw it and told me that I will be a very good hunter in the future.

S.FORM: mi’ocu saasmoyʉskʉ, os’o ngoevi ’o fsyunoaʉlʉ fiho to amo ho e’ohʉ.
S.TRANSL: 現在我長大了，我背起我的弓和箭矢，跟著爸爸一起去打獵。
Now that I have grown up, I carry my bow and arrows and go hunting with my father.

S.FORM: maine’e to huehungu angaeza ’o isi poumia ci yuansou ho angaezneni to ma’o’oahngʉ.
S.TRANSL: 回村時將獵到的獵物和族人們分享。
When returning to the village, share the hunted prey with the tribe.

S.FORM: yainca to amo, teto’la to’aveoveoyʉ nola pocengi, tela ko’ko man’i na teto’la tov’oha ci yuansou.
S.TRANSL: 爸爸說，我們要感謝祖靈賜福，讓我們有很多獵物收穫。
Dad said, we want to thank the ancestors for their blessings, so that we have a lot of prey to harvest.

S.FORM: mi’o poha’o ne taseona ne te’o toatmopsʉ.
S.TRANSL: 我早上上學遲到了。
I was late for school this morning.

S.FORM: me mi’o uhune ’oyonatmpsʉ, os’o ta’payo’a hafa ’o tvotposʉa.
S.TRANSL: 去學校的時候，我忘了帶書包。
When I was going to school, I forgot to bring my backpack.

S.FORM: uk’a ci os’o hafa ci macucuma.
S.TRANSL: 我什麼東西都沒有帶。
I didn’t bring anything with me.

S.FORM: mo seo’lʉa no tmopsʉ, mimia iepoepohʉ baito to tposʉ ’o mimia tmepoepohʉ.
S.TRANSL: 上課的時候，我和同學一起看課本。
During class, I and my classmates read the textbook together.

S.FORM: sio’lʉa no hʉsvʉta, yuevaha to mimia tmaepoepohʉ ’o ’oyomza tmopsʉ’u ho ’oyomza smaofsusu.
S.TRANSL: 考試的時候，同學借我筆和橡皮擦。
During the exam, a classmate lent me a pen and an eraser.

S.FORM: mi’uni a’o to le’aotothomʉ ho yainca, “takocula yue’ou’ou no ta’esi, ’ote na’la ’aoko poha’o!”
S.TRANSL: 老師跟我說：「下次早點起床，不要再遲到了!」
The teacher told me, “Wake up earlier next time and don’t be late again!”

S.FORM: ’o nanghia’u zou pasuya, zou maezo oko no cou to psoseongana.
S.TRANSL: 我的好朋友叫pasuya，他也是鄒族的小孩。
My good friend’s name is pasuya, and he is also an Cou child.

S.FORM: lamia iepoepohʉ toatmopsʉ to you ne saviki.
S.TRANSL: 我們一起在山美部落讀書。
We study together in the saviki tribe.

S.FORM: lamia asngʉcʉ iepoepohʉ tma’lʉ to mameoi hola ehohamo, lamia acʉhʉ na’no melʉ bua cou.
S.TRANSL: 我們常常一起聽耆老說故事，我們都很會說鄒語。
We often listen to the elders telling stories together, and we both can speak the Cou proficiently.

S.FORM: mi’o na’no bankake ho maezo na’no noyʉnʉ, mita na ’no putisi ’e pasuya ho maezo na ’no kʉehoi.
S.TRANSL: 我很高也很胖，pasuya很矮也很瘦。
I am tall and overweight, while pasuya is short and thin.

S.FORM: mo na’ no peiseayayokeo ’o pasuya, la toehunga ʉmnʉa.
S.TRANSL: pasuya很有活力，大家都很喜歡他。
pasuya is very energetic, and everyone likes him a lot.

S.FORM: maitan’e zou meesi no ’untoo ’to ’oyona tmopsʉ, man’i ’o isi hioa ci yupatoosa’o to ’oyona tmopsʉ.
S.TRANSL: 今天是學校的運動會，學校舉辦了許多競賽。
Today was the school's sports day, and the school organized many competitions.

S.FORM: moyaa yupa e’tʉyʉ, mo’potʉ to mali, toosa’o no mayahe, ’otole, pono to yanosuyu.
S.TRANSL: 有拔河、足球、跑步、跳舞和射箭。
There were tug of war, soccer, running, dancing, and archery.

S.FORM: mi’o toosa’o no peyayofʉ.
S.TRANSL: 我比賽跑步。
I participated in the running competition.

S.FORM: ne mi’o seo’lʉa no peyaofʉ, mi’o smopcuku, meoino yuhmuyu ’o ka’li.
S.TRANSL: 當我跑步的時候，我跌倒了，膝蓋流了很多血。
When I was running, I fell down, and my knees were bleeding.

S.FORM: at’inghi mi’o yac’ʉ, mi’o acʉ’cʉnʉ peyayofʉ.
S.TRANSL: 但我站起來，繼續向前跑。
But I stood up and continued running forward.

S.FORM: ne mi’ocu seolʉa no toepaezumo mo acʉhʉ na’na kokaekaebʉ.
S.TRANSL: 我到終點時所有人都很開心。
Everyone was happy when I reached the finish line.

S.FORM: ’evono o’ami’o somayahea, at’inghi mi’o na’na kokaekaebʉ, maica ho os’ocu aepʉnga na’e yupa toosa’o.
S.TRANSL: 雖然沒有獲得第一名，但我很高興，因為我完成了比賽。
Although I didn't get first place, I'm glad because I completed the race.

S.FORM: ne hucma a’o ho amo imia usa aiti ’o amo’u coni.
S.TRANSL: 昨天我和爸爸去拜訪我的叔叔。
Yesterday, my father and I visited my uncle.

S.FORM: mo alolongʉ ’o t’ango to amoconi.
S.TRANSL: 叔叔的腳受傷了。
My uncle injured his foot.

S.FORM: isi eʉsvʉta a’mi, ’o patingsoha to sofʉ mo meoino ah’ʉtʉ.
S.TRANSL: 他告訴我們，房子的屋頂破了一個洞。
He told us that there was a hole in the roof of his house.

S.FORM: ne isi seolʉa no teovahi ’o sofʉ. i’mi to patingsoha to sofʉ ho supeohʉ.
S.TRANSL: 他在修理屋頂時，從屋頂摔下來了。
He fell off the roof while repairing it.

S.FORM: mo mahafo to fou ‘uachumu ho fi’i ’o amo’u ho faeni to amoconi.
S.TRANSL: 爸爸帶了牛肉和檳榔給叔叔。
My father brought beef and betel nuts for my uncle.

S.FORM: a’o ho amoconi mimia yontola yoni amiocni ho yupeahngʉyʉ, mo man’i ’o isi aangaezneni ci h’oehohanva.
S.TRANSL: 我和叔叔在房間裡聊天，他分享了很多故事。
My uncle and I chatted in the room, and he shared many stories.

S.FORM: auyusi ne teo’cu mongoi, emomoengʉa to amoconi ho mi’ocu yubankake, maezo asuhcu mʉʉlʉlʉ.
S.TRANSL: 我要離開前，叔叔誇我長高了，也變得更帥氣了。
Before I left, my uncle praised me for growing taller and becoming more handsome.

S.FORM: os’o yainca, “toteni ho tac’u yov’o ’o t’angosi, maezo sio uhta emoo’u no ta’esi.”
S.TRANSL: 我說：「等叔叔腳好了，下次也來我們家玩。」
I said, “When your foot gets better, come to our house next time and visit us.”

S.FORM: nemoso tonsoha no 2022, ’o ’oyonatmopsʉ kaingi ho toʉsvʉsvʉtneni te peela aleonga poa ongko ta cou ’e mivunso.
S.TRANSL: 在2022年，政府召開了原住民身分證可單列族名的會議。
In 2022, the government announced that indigenous identification cards can include tribal names separately.

S.FORM: os’o tuocosi ’ola auesiesi mi’usnu to ’oyonatmopsʉ ho pnanfi no tata’ia aleonga poa bua coua ’e mivnsoou ta cou ci foinana to you ci pasu’e yasiungu.
S.TRANSL: 我訪問了長期向政府爭取身分證「單列族名」的部落青年pasu’e yasiungu。
I interviewed pasu’e yasiungu, a young tribal member who has long been advocating for the inclusion of tribal names on identification cards.

S.FORM: mimia yu’tasvʉtʉ hotena seolʉa no tosvo ho uhto emoosi ho aiti.
S.TRANSL: 我和他約定好這個假日到他家訪問他。
We had arranged to visit his home this holiday for the interview.

S.FORM: to taicosi ne os’o tucocosi, isi eʉsvʉta na isi i’mizi to ongkosi, isi yaeza poa hongneni ’o iachisi emoo ho yousi.
S.TRANSL: 在訪問的過程中，他向我介紹了他的名字的由來，也帶我認識了他的家人、他的部落。
During the interview, he introduced to me the origin of his name and also introduced me to his family and tribe.

S.FORM: os’o tuocosi maincis’a na’no bitotonʉ no taezuhi si ongkosu, o’amo ʉmnʉ ’o micu aesiei cila hia tmopsʉa?
S.TRANSL: 我問他為什麼堅持要改名，舊的登記方式不好嗎?
I asked him why he insisted on changing his name. Wasn’t the old registration method sufficient?

S.FORM: mi’usnu a’o ho yainca, mo’so maica homo boemi to tmapuutu ho tposi ’e ongko, o’aisis’a a’sʉftona etuhca hoisi psoevaha ’e ongkosi, ’o mocmo ci cou lahen’a yainca “巴先生” i’mi tamo maica ho man’i isi koa cocvi.
S.TRANSL: \" which resulted in many jokes being made."
He told me that using Chinese characters could not accurately convey his name, and others would still call him \Ba Xian Sheng

S.FORM: yainca to pasuya, “na aʉmtʉ ongkoto ’aeno ’e isi uanenicou ho tposi ci ongko na aʉmtʉ ongkoto. ’e ongko’u zou ongko to ’oahngʉ’u, zou ongko to mimia conoemoo, zou ongko mia, tata’ia te asuhcu botngonʉ nate pela e’lʉa na iachi ongko.”
S.TRANSL: our family
pasuya said, \The names written in indigenous languages are our true names. My name represents our ethnic group

S.FORM: ne hucma mimia yuyuso ’e ba’i ho uhtola toehunga hoteyuni mhinmhino te soovai, ’o ba’i mo mahafo to isi iachia emʉ’a ci machachae te soovai, maezo moyai to mafe cila ana to cou ci ’oanʉ ho faeni tomo batngonʉ.
S.TRANSL: 昨天我跟奶奶去市集擺攤，奶奶帶了許多自己種的蔬菜去，也製作了原住民美食給大家。
Yesterday, I went to the market with my grandmother to set up a stall. My grandmother brought a lot of vegetables that she grew herself and also prepared indigenous cuisine for everyone.

S.FORM: ihe na’na ʉmnʉa ’o soovai to ba’i, ’o cuc’u ho tomato mo botngonʉ ’omo mhino, botngonʉ ‘omo uso ho oothomʉ to isi pei’i ci chae.
S.TRANSL: 大家很喜歡奶奶的攤位，辣椒和車輪茄很多人買，許多人來品嘗她煮的菜餚。
Everyone loved my grandmother’s stall. Many people bought the chilis and African eggplants, and many people came to taste the dishes she cooked.

S.FORM: ’oisi pei’i ci chae hʉngʉ ho ufi na’no mafe, ho i’o isi titheni to fou fuzu ho toeteuyuni pei’i ’o ma’fʉ ci fou, ’o na’ausnasi ihe na’no kaeba tomo botngonʉ ci cou, acʉhʉ uhto soovaimia ho bitoyange.
S.TRANSL: 她煮的蕨菜和糯米飯非常好吃，還有用山豬肉煮的馬告滷肉，味道吸引了很多客人，大家都來我們攤位排隊。
The ferns and sticky rice she cooked were delicious, as well as the braised pork with maqaw pepper and wild boar meat. The flavors attracted many customers, and everyone lined up at our stall.

S.FORM: nemo seolʉa no apapeipei’i ’o ba’i, mi’o yonto ciengonasi ho meukokosʉ tomo sucocafi ci cou. mi’o yonto ciengonasi tmunoi moozoyʉ, “’e chae c’o acʉha iachia emʉ’a, acʉhʉ yʉ’ʉ’ʉmni ci chae, aupcio mhino!
S.TRANSL: all-natural and organic! Come and buy now!\""
While my grandmother was cooking, I was on the side attracting customers. I shouted, \The vegetables are self-grown

S.FORM: ’o macucumamia c’o osnia psʉepʉngneni, yainca to ba’i, “moc’o acʉhʉ i’mi ho miso to’usnu.”
S.TRANSL: 我們的東西很快就賣完了，奶奶說：「都是因為有你的幫忙。」
Our goods sold out quickly, and my grandmother said, “It’s all thanks to your help.”

S.FORM: ’emo maica ci hi’hioa, mi’o tov’ohʉ ta nat’ʉca no cacʉfea ta cou ho mau’to’tohʉngʉ no ma’o’oanʉ, avinano peela cohivi na ngoseo tala soovai.
S.TRANSL: 這個活動，我學到了有關原住民植物和食品的知識，並且體驗到了擺攤的辛苦。
Through this event, I learned about indigenous plants and food and experienced the hard work of running a stall.

S.FORM: aiti ’e ba’i ho lata aʉmtʉ soekaibʉ ta ma’o’oanʉ, os’o iachia na’na itanvevi ho yaa ta’usnia.
S.TRANSL: 看到了奶奶對傳統食物的熱愛，我感到非常驕傲和榮幸。
Seeing my grandmother’s passion for traditional food, I feel very proud and honored.
